symptoms: Velvety, olive-green or brown circular spots appear on the undersides of leaves and fruit.
Twisting, yellowing, and premature drop of leaves occur in severe infections.
Deformities, cracking, and small 'pinpoint' spots develop on the fruit.
treatment: Apply fungicides regularly during high-risk periods like the pink bud stage.
Rotate fungicides with different mechanisms of action to prevent resistance.
Collect and destroy infected leaves and fruits to maintain orchard sanitation.
prevention: Choose apple varieties that are genetically resistant to the disease.
Apply a 5% urea solution to fallen leaves in autumn to accelerate decay.
Prune trees to allow better air circulation for faster leaf drying.

symptoms: Small purple specks on leaves enlarge to circular spots with tan centers and purple margins.
Firm, reddish-brown to black rot appears on fruit, forming concentric rings.
Fruit shrivels, dries out, and remains on the tree as 'mummies'.
treatment: Prune out dead wood, fire blight strikes, and cankers where the fungus overwinters.
Apply fungicides such as Captan or sulfur from silver tip through harvest.
Remove and destroy mummified fruits from the tree and the orchard floor.
prevention: Prune trees annually to increase air circulation and light penetration.
Remove prunings from the orchard or chop them to accelerate decomposition.
Maintain tree vigor to reduce stress and prevent canker formation.

symptoms: Small, pale yellow-orange spots appear on upper leaf surfaces, with orange protuberances on the undersides.
Fruit develops superficial lesions at the blossom end, causing disfigurement.
Infected leaves may yellow and drop prematurely in severe cases.
treatment: Once lesions are visible, control is impossible; apply preventative fungicides immediately.
Preventative fungicides like Mancozeb should be applied starting at the pink bud stage.
There are no effective organic fungicide options available for this disease.
prevention: Remove Eastern Red Cedar trees located near the orchard to eliminate the host.
Select and plant apple varieties that are resistant to rust diseases.

symptoms: Infected leaves curl upward and may become distorted.
Newly developed leaves become progressively smaller and pale.
By midseason, a whitish fungus covering leaves and shoots becomes visible.
treatment: Begin chemical control no later than petal fall and apply fungicides until harvest.
Apply fungicides from FRAC Groups 3, 7, and 11 as the disease develops.
Products specific to powdery mildew, such as Quintec or Vivando, can be used.
prevention: Prune trees to ensure good air circulation within the canopy.
Keep grass mowed in the orchard to reduce humidity levels.
Monitor closely in shaded areas or during periods of high humidity.

symptoms: Distinct rectangular lesions develop, restricted by leaf veins, giving them a 'matchstick' shape.
Lesions eventually merge, causing large areas of leaf tissue to dry out and die.
Symptoms typically begin on lower leaves and progress upward rapidly in humid conditions.
treatment: Apply fungicides (Strobilurins or Triazoles) between tasseling and silking stages.
Fungicide application is crucial for susceptible hybrids during humid weather.
Since the fungus survives in residue, tillage can reduce inoculum levels.
prevention: Planting corn hybrids with genetic resistance is the most effective control method.
Practice crop rotation with soybeans for at least 1-2 years to break the cycle.
Avoid excessive planting density to improve air circulation within the canopy.

symptoms: Cinnamon-brown, raised pustules appear on both upper and lower leaf surfaces.
Pustules rupture to release powdery spores and turn black late in the season.
Disease favors cool, moist conditions and can reduce grain fill.
treatment: In most cases, the disease does not reach economic thresholds requiring fungicide application.
Fungicides may be beneficial only if infection is severe on susceptible hybrids.
Do not confuse with Southern Rust, which is more aggressive.
prevention: The most effective control is planting corn hybrids with high genetic resistance.
Avoid late planting, as late-planted corn is exposed to higher spore loads.
Maintain plant health through soil analysis and balanced fertilization.

symptoms: Long, elliptical, grayish-green or tan lesions develop, described as 'cigar-shaped'.
As the disease progresses, lesions coalesce, causing large areas of the leaf to die.
In humid conditions, dark, olive-green 'sooty' spores may be visible in the center of lesions.
treatment: Fungicide application is effective if lesions are present on the ear leaf during tasseling.
Since the fungus overwinters in residue, tillage can bury debris and reduce inoculum.
Early management is crucial as the disease destroys photosynthetic tissue.
prevention: The primary control method is planting corn hybrids with specific resistance genes.
Practice crop rotation; do not plant corn continuously in the same field.
Manage planting density to ensure adequate air circulation.

symptoms: Reddish-brown, circular lesions appear on the upper leaf surface with a dark border.
Small, black, pimple-like fruiting bodies appear in the center of mature lesions.
Infected berries turn dark brown, shrivel into hard 'mummies', and remain on the cluster.
treatment: Remove, burn, or bury infected prunings and mummified berries before spring.
Apply fungicides from early season through fruit coloring in high-risk vineyards.
Monitor leaf wetness and temperature to time fungicide sprays effectively.
prevention: Plant grape varieties that are resistant to black rot.
Prune vines to allow sunlight penetration and air circulation.
Complete sanitation practices before the growing season starts.

symptoms: Leaves develop yellow or red necrotic stripes, creating a 'tiger-stripe' pattern.
Small, round, dark spots bordered by a purple ring appear on the berries.
In severe cases, the vine may suddenly wither or drop all its leaves.
treatment: Chemical control is not curative as the disease resides deep within the wood.
Protect pruning wounds immediately after cutting by applying paints or pastes.
Use the 'double pruning' technique during the dormant season to reduce risk.
prevention: Avoid pruning during rainy weather, as rain helps disperse fungal spores.
Remove and burn infected trunks or cordons from the vineyard.
Maintain vine vigor by preventing water and nutrient stress.

symptoms: Large, irregular spots appear on leaves, turning black and brittle with age.
The centers of lesions may drop, giving the leaves a shot-hole appearance.
Severe infection leads to premature defoliation, reducing fruit quality.
treatment: Fungicides containing mancozeb, copper, or Bordeaux mixture are effective.
Begin fungicide applications when shoots are 2-4 inches long.
Continue applications into the post-harvest period to protect foliage.
prevention: Practice canopy management to increase air circulation and reduce humidity.
Collect and destroy fallen infected leaves in winter to reduce infection sources.

symptoms: Leaves show asymmetrical yellow mottling that crosses leaf veins.
Fruit often remains green at the bottom, grows lopsided, and tastes bitter.
Yellow shoots appear in the canopy, followed by twig dieback and tree death.
treatment: There is no cure; infected trees will not recover and should be removed.
Apply approved insecticides to control the Asian Citrus Psyllid vector.
Enhanced nutritional programs may prolong tree life but do not cure the infection.
prevention: Plant only certified disease-free nursery trees grown in insect-proof structures.
Scout regularly for the psyllid vector and implement controls immediately.
Remove suspected infected trees immediately after confirmation.

symptoms: Leaves develop angular, purple-black spots; centers drop out, creating a 'shot-hole' effect.
Fruit develops pitting, cracking, and gumming, making them susceptible to rots.
Severe infection leads to premature yellowing and defoliation.
treatment: Apply copper compounds from bud swell to bloom.
Use antibiotics like Oxytetracycline during and after bloom instead of copper.
Apply Bordeaux mixture during the dormant season to reduce bacterial population.
prevention: Selecting peach varieties genetically resistant to bacterial spot is effective.
Plant windbreaks to prevent sand from causing micro-wounds on leaves.
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization, as fast-growing tissue is more susceptible.

symptoms: Leaves develop small, water-soaked spots that turn dark brown or black.
Raised, brown, wart-like lesions appear on the fruit, rendering them unmarketable.
Severe infection causes leaves to drop, leading to sunscald on the fruit.
treatment: Apply copper fungicides mixed with Mancozeb to overcome copper resistance.
Avoid working in the field when plants are wet to prevent bacterial spread.
Remove and destroy severely infected plants to prevent spread.
prevention: The most effective control is planting certified resistant varieties.
Treat seeds with hot water or calcium hypochlorite before planting.
Practice crop rotation; do not plant peppers or tomatoes for 2-3 years.

symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings resembling a 'bullseye' appear on older leaves.
Lesions are often surrounded by a yellow halo; leaves eventually dry up.
Tubers develop dark, sunken, leathery, and dry rot lesions.
treatment: Apply protectant fungicides like Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil preventatively.
Once established, switch to systemic fungicides and rotate them.
Desiccate vines at least 2 weeks before harvest to reduce tuber infection.
prevention: Rotate crops and avoid planting solanaceous crops in the same field for 3-4 years.
Manage plant stress through proper irrigation and balanced fertilization.
Remove or bury crop debris after harvest to eliminate overwintering sites.

symptoms: Leaves develop pale green, water-soaked spots that turn dark brown rapidly.
In humid conditions, a white, cottony mold appears on the undersides of leaves.
Tubers develop a reddish-brown, granular, firm rot beneath the skin.
treatment: Apply protective fungicides like Chlorothalonil immediately upon detection.
If infection is established, switch to systemic fungicides specific for oomycetes.
Kill vines 2-3 weeks before harvest to prevent spores from infecting tubers.
prevention: Always plant certified, disease-free seed potatoes.
Destroy all cull piles near the field as they are primary inoculum sources.
Widen row spacing and avoid excessive irrigation to reduce humidity.

symptoms: A white, dusty growth appears on leaves, stems, and petioles.
Infected leaves eventually turn yellow, brown, and dry out.
Premature loss of foliage exposes the fruit to sunscald and reduces quality.
treatment: Apply products containing Sulfur, Neem oil, or Potassium Bicarbonate immediately.
Systemic fungicides can be used but must be rotated to prevent resistance.
Use caution with sulfur; do not apply when temperatures exceed 32Â°C.
prevention: Plant varieties that are genetically resistant (PMR) to powdery mildew.
Increase plant spacing to ensure good air circulation.
Keep the garden free of weeds that serve as overwintering hosts.

symptoms: Numerous small, irregular purple spots appear on leaves without white centers.
Spots enlarge and coalesce, giving the leaf a burnt appearance.
In severe cases, leaf margins curl upward, taking on a cup-like shape.
treatment: Protective fungicides containing Captan or Thiram can be applied until harvest.
Mowing off old foliage immediately after harvest reduces infection sources.
Never leave infected leaves in the field, as the fungus overwinters there.
prevention: Plant strawberry varieties that are resistant to Leaf Scorch.
Increase air circulation by controlling weeds and proper plant spacing.
Use drip irrigation if possible; overhead irrigation promotes disease spread.

symptoms: Leaves develop small, water-soaked, dark brown spots without a yellow halo.
Fruit develops raised, brown, scabby lesions, reducing marketability.
Advanced infection causes a scorched appearance and defoliation.
treatment: Apply copper bactericides mixed with Mancozeb to prevent resistance.
Never prune or harvest plants when the foliage is wet.
Inspect seedlings carefully and discard any that show signs of infection.
prevention: Use only certified disease-free seeds; treat seeds with hot water if possible.
Practice crop rotation; avoid planting tomatoes or peppers for 2-3 years.
Use drip irrigation instead of overhead sprinklers to keep foliage dry.

symptoms: Brown spots with concentric rings resembling a 'bullseye' appear on lower leaves.
Tissue surrounding the spots turns yellow; leaves eventually dry up and drop.
Dark, sunken, leathery rot with concentric rings develops on the fruit.
treatment: Prune lower leaves and stake plants to improve air circulation.
Apply protective fungicides containing Copper or Chlorothalonil preventatively.
Remove infected foliage during dry weather conditions.
prevention: Apply mulch around the base of plants to prevent soil-borne spore splash.
Practice crop rotation; do not plant tomatoes or potatoes for 3 years.
Use drip irrigation instead of overhead watering.

symptoms: Large, water-soaked spots appear on leaves, rapidly turning dark brown.
In humid weather, a white mold appears on the undersides of leaves.
Fruit develops firm, dark brown, greasy-looking spots with a rough surface.
treatment: Immediately remove and destroy infected plants by bagging them.
Apply protective fungicides containing Chlorothalonil or Copper to healthy plants.
In organic gardening, copper-based products can help slow the spread.
prevention: The most effective strategy is to plant resistant tomato varieties.
Avoid wetting the foliage; use drip irrigation and ensure wide spacing.
Use only certified disease-free seeds and transplants.

symptoms: Pale yellow spots with undefined margins appear on the upper leaf surface.
An olive-green, velvety mold growth develops on the undersides of leaves.
Disease starts on lower leaves; severe infection causes leaves to wither.
treatment: Increase ventilation to reduce relative humidity below 85% in greenhouses.
Apply fungicides containing Copper or Chlorothalonil upon first detection.
Carefully prune and remove severely infected lower leaves.
prevention: Choose tomato varieties explicitly labeled as resistant to Leaf Mold.
Ensure wide plant spacing and prune plants to facilitate airflow.
Use drip irrigation to keep foliage dry and reduce infection risk.

symptoms: Numerous small, circular spots with dark margins and gray centers appear.
Tiny black dots (pycnidia) are visible in the center of the gray spots.
Unlike Early Blight, this disease rarely affects the fruit itself.
treatment: Prune and remove infected lower leaves immediately.
Apply fungicides containing Chlorothalonil or Copper upon first symptoms.
Remove and destroy all crop debris at the end of the season.
prevention: Apply mulch around the base of plants to prevent spore splash.
Practice a 3-year crop rotation for solanaceous crops.
Use drip irrigation and water early in the day.

symptoms: Tiny yellow or whitish specks appear on the upper leaf surface.
As populations increase, fine silk webbing becomes visible on leaves.
In severe infestations, leaves turn bronze, dry out, and drop.
treatment: Avoid broad-spectrum insecticides; they cause mite populations to flare up.
Use high-pressure water sprays, insecticidal soaps, or Neem oil.
For commercial production, use specific miticides.
prevention: Reduce dust by watering pathways, as mites thrive in dusty conditions.
Release predatory mites as a biological control method.
Remove weeds in and around the field to eliminate overwintering hosts.

symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings appear; often with a yellow halo.
The centers of lesions often drop out, leaving 'shot-holes'.
Fruit develops brown, sunken lesions that typically crack open.
treatment: Apply protective fungicides containing Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb.
Avoid using Strobilurin fungicides alone due to resistance issues.
Prune lower leaves to improve air circulation.
prevention: Increase airflow in the greenhouse or field to reduce leaf wetness.
Control weeds around the field, as they can host the pathogen.
Destroy all crop debris after harvest.

symptoms: Leaves curl upward (cupping), become small, and develop yellow margins.
Plants become severely stunted with bushy new growth.
Flowers drop before fruit set; fruits remain small and fail to ripen.
treatment: There is no cure; infected plants must be removed and destroyed immediately.
Control the Silverleaf Whitefly vector using Neem oil or insecticides.
Sanitation of tools is less critical as the virus is not mechanically transmitted.
prevention: The most effective solution is to plant resistant tomato varieties.
Use reflective mulches to repel whiteflies.
Protect young transplants with fine-mesh row covers.

symptoms: Leaves develop a characteristic 'mosaic' pattern of light and dark green.
In some cases, leaves become distorted, stringy, or twisted.
Fruits may show internal browning or ripen unevenly.
treatment: There is no cure; immediately remove and destroy infected plants.
Disinfect hands and tools frequently using a bleach solution or milk.
Always work with healthy plants first to prevent mechanical transmission.
prevention: Smokers must wash hands before handling plants, as tobacco carries the virus.
Use certified seeds and varieties resistant to Mosaic Virus.
Practice a 2-year crop rotation to eliminate soil-borne virus.
